speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 1314-87, Henderson v. The United States. Mr. Ortiz.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why isn't -- is that enough for your client?  He wants to sell the firearms to -- the government is willing to let a licensed firearms dealer sell them for him?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did -- I didn't -- I thought that before the district court there was only first, his friend, then his mother, and then another friend.  Where -- where did he ask the court to allow the guns to be sold by a licensed gun dealer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But that doesn't mention anything about a gun dealer, and he had been quite specific about the persons to whom he wanted the guns transferred.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is there any point in the Alderson Reporting Company references that you made where he said to the court, "I would like these guns to be consigned to a licensed gun dealer?‚Äù

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Wasn't he on a futile mission in this circuit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Because this circuit had already ruled that any kind of sale by anyone was prohibited, because he was a felon.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And when he went up on appeal, he cited the Brown case to the court -- to the circuit court, which had held that a court-ordered sale was okay. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And despite him citing the Brown case, the Eighth Circuit continued with its own precedent and said no one can sell it, not even the court.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I would have thought -- I would have thought you would oppose the notion that that would be an adequate -- adequate relief.  If we're talking about an attribute of ownership, the owner gets to decide who -- to whom he's going to sell what he owns.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How do you -- how does one tell -- let's take the two people -- two friends that you opposed -- suggested transferring them to, or his wife so they could stay within the family.  How does the Court know whether that transfer will give him access to the guns so that he will have possession?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And under what statutory rule or authority does the court hold that hearing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is there a black-letter case you can cite for the proposition that the court has this general equitable authority?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Because I'm wondering if the government wants to sue under the Tucker Act or something.  That's what I'm asking.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: You agree that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And 41(g) is too much of a stretch?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But it's not just return; right?  It's return the property to the movant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So how does this fit under 41(g)?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: He's asking for the stick and the bundle that's called ownership and -- and the funds from the transfer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Just so I understand the scope of your position, you say that the district court has discretion to figure out, you know, whether a particular person whom your client or someone else wants to sell the gun to is an appropriate recipient of the gun.  But in the absence of that, does the district court just have discretion or must the district court ensure that the gun is sold through a gun dealer? In other words, if -- if your client says really I want it sold through a gun dealer, is that Alderson Reporting Company discretionary on the district court's part or is that required?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry, would you repeat that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Can I ask you a question about your argument that a district court would have the discretion to prevent the transfer of a gun from the convicted felon to a third party who has some acquaintance with the convicted felon?  A friend, let's say.  Let's say it's a friend who lives two blocks away. Now, if this friend doesn't -- is not himself a convicted felon or doesn't have some other aspect of his record that would prevent him from buying a firearm, he could go to a licensed firearm dealer, presumably, and Alderson Reporting Company purchase it directly; right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So why should the situation -- and that would be true even though he is a friend of the convicted felon, and there might be some risk that he would allow the convicted felon to use the firearm. So why should the situation be different when the district court is considering whether the firearm can be transferred from the convicted felon to this individual?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But I thought you understood -- I thought  you were saying that the district court would have the discretion to prevent that transfer if the district court thought there was some risk that this individual would allow the convicted felon to have access to the firearm.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And then that individual could go to the --the licensed firearm dealer and buy exactly the same gun.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So I don't see how the two positions are --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And who -- who makes the arrangement?  Who selects the gun dealer and makes the Alderson Reporting Company arrangement for the consignment?  Does the court do that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- or does Henderson do it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And, Mr. --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I would assume it ought to be the gun owner's first preference.  I mean, why -- why wouldn't that be the normal situation?  His first preference is that it -- it should be sold to -- to individual X.  And if the court cannot reject that, it should go there.  And his second preference is, well, if you reject that, give it to Y.  Wouldn't that be the normal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I think Justice Alito's question is basically why would the district court have equitable power to turn down any named buyer so long as Alderson Reporting Company it is an actual buyer.  Meaning I can understand he can't just designate someone who's himself, okay, but if he's making a good faith sale, why should the district court have any power to turn that person down?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And, Mr. Ortiz, why -- why is it required that the court arrange for some transfer, whether to a gun dealer or otherwise?  Is it principles of equity that require that?  Is it something else?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: There -- there's no statutory bar, but I guess I'm asking a further question because you said in response to my earlier question it's not just discretionary, it's required, you know, at Alderson Reporting Company least to a gun dealer.  And -- and I guess I'm asking: What is the source of that requirement?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Ms. O'Connell.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Where did it -- the ability to sell something depends upon ownership, not possession.  If I leave my car with a garage for a month, the garage has possession, but they can't sell the car.  I don't have possession, but I can sell the car. In other words, I don't see how it gets to be constructive possession.  All he's asserting is a right to ownership, which carries with it the right to sell.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But he doesn't -- he doesn't have much control when the government is holding them.  He's -- he's just trying to sell them.  He doesn't want to control them.  He doesn't want to use them.  He doesn't want to possess them, constructively or otherwise.  In fact, he wants to get rid of them, which is what the statute is supposed to accomplish.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But do you think that the -- the person can pick the firearms dealer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, then your -- your position is internally contradictory, right?  You think he can pick the firearms dealer.  Well, that's -- that fits within your very broad definition of control.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, then suppose his friend comes forward and says, I don't really intend to possess this.  I'm going to sell it. That wouldn't be control?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why -- well, why do you say that constructive possession only consists of being able to decide where they go?  Why isn't it constructive possession to be able to decide who gets them for later transfer?  Why doesn't -- why isn't that an exercise --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- of -- of dominion over them to some extent?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I want so-and-so to sell them.  I -- I don't know why that isn't exercising dominion and control.  It seems to me you're drawing a very artificial line.  You only -- you -- you can only exercise dominion and control when you determine where they end up, but I -- I don't see that that comes within -- within the term "constructive possession."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm not saying it doesn't make sense.  I mean, it may make a lot of sense and may be a very good policy had it been written into this statute.  But you're building this whole -- this -- this whole palace upon the word "constructive possession." And I don't see how constructive possession makes -- makes that distinction.  It really doesn't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't think it's harder at all.  He's deciding where they go for sale.  Why isn't that exercising dominion and control?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What if -- what if he wants to donate them to someone?  He wants to donate them to the Texas National Guard?  Could he do that?  I mean, the -- the Federal firearms dealer doesn't help you there.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, I mean, no, he can't do it or --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: To the Federal government he says, I -- I'm sorry about the conviction. I want to give these to the Federal government. Can he do that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I -- I guess that's what he's doing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why isn't that exercising dominion and control?  I mean, he says, I'm not going to propose anything.  I'm going to let the Federal government have them. Why isn't that exercising dominion --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, lucky you. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Ms. O'Connell, can I ask why -- why it is that we're looking at it in terms of the sale?  I mean, this is -- this constructive possession question, it would seem to me to make a lot more sense to ask the person who's going to end up getting it, is there a chance that the original owner can control what that person does with it. In other words, you know, I give it to my wife, I give it to my best friend, and I'm really in a position where I'm controlling the use of the firearm. And that seems to me to make perfect sense, not the Alderson Reporting Company question of, like, who controls the sale mechanism.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Where does all this come from?  I mean, to me, when somebody uses the word "constructive X," that just means it's not X and -- and it's a way of pretending that it's X when it isn't. So I start with that and say what you're worried about here -- of course, he doesn't have any possession of it.  You have possession of it.  And what he wants to do is he wants to put it somewhere so he can't get ahold of it as long as the law prevents him from having it.  And you took it from him.  You made him give it to him. So what's wrong with his saying, you go give it to somebody?  Now, if it's too much trouble, the judge can say he can't make you go to a lot of trouble. If it's giving it to somebody who might really do everything he wants, we'll guard against that.  That's the job of the district judge.  End of case. Now, what -- what's -- what's -- simple, Alderson Reporting Company realistic, preserves the government's interest.  What's wrong with it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- things like that, and I don't understand any piece of it that has something in that like it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  So we don't want them.  So we'll say to the district judge, Judge, use some common sense.  Don't let this gun get into the hands of the crime boss of the area.  Don't let the Alderson Reporting Company things that you were just talking about happen. And you look to see how much trouble it is, what's likely to happen, and where it makes sense.  And if it isn't likely for these bad things to happen, fine.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But that seems to me very different than the situation here, Ms. O'Connell, because in that case, what the gang leader has is a situation where somebody else is holding a gun for him and he can say anything to that person.  He can say, Use the gun.  He can say, Keep the gun in your closet.  He can say, Sell it to Person A or Person B or Person C. He has total freedom over it. And that's very different from the situation here where the only thing that a person would -- a person in Mr. Henderson's position can do is to sell the gun to a person whom the court approves.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yeah, but he doesn't -- he doesn't have to get anybody to approve the buyer.  I think what Justice Kagan is saying, it's -- it's a lot harder to say you have dominion and control when you have to come before an equity court and say, Please, may I, you know -- please may I have -- have the gun given to my best friend or to somebody else.  That doesn't sound much like dominion and control to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, the reality is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is this --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The reality is that the world is not going to know the guns are there, so -- but there's no exclusion.  If I wanted to go into that case and ask the court to consider me rather than the nominee, it's a court of equity.  And the court could say I'm the better owner than the person they nominated. So I don't know what this -- why this nomination becomes control over the sale if it's the judge who's approving the sale.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, you're saying the court is the one who decides whether the person who's nominated is appropriate or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But what is it you want to have happen; that is, the gun was taken away from him.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: He can't possess it anymore.  It's in the hands of the court, I guess, or the government.  Okay. Now, it's his.        It's a 1891 collector's item; he's a gun collector.  Nobody is claiming it's forfeitable, or anything.  Okay.  What do you think should happen?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But the idea -- the idea that it should be sold through a Federal firearms dealer is a late idea.  This was not something the Alderson Reporting Company government proposed at any stage below until the case came here, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, what did you anticipate -- what was your position before you changed it here in this Court about what should happen to the guns?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Has the Federal government ever used these guns?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Not these particular ones but guns that were forfeited by a convicted felon and someone who couldn't sell them to anyone, at least until you changed the position and said they could sell Alderson Reporting Company them to a firearms dealer?  They just sat around gathering dust?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, that wouldn't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But the same trap that you're -- I'm a little bit upset at your brief, frankly, because in that circuit, he couldn't know that there was any permissible sale, because that circuit had said none. And so to come back and say to us that we should leave it in their discretion as to whether it should go to a -- a Federal -- a federally licensed firearms dealer seems as if the government has set a trap for a pro se litigant.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That's not -- that's not going to get it done.  You still have the problem of the court below's view of the Unclean Hands Doctrine. Do you have a position, the Federal government -- does the Federal Government have a position on that doctrine Alderson Reporting Company now?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is that going to be your -- your position -- I mean, because I'm getting away from the -- what I call the legal mumbo-jumbo.  Looking at the word "possessed" there, fine.  It's a question of interpreting that.  And now where I thought, well, he can't just have it sold to anybody.  I mean, it could be sold -- you don't want it sold to somebody who's going to do his bidding every five minutes.  I mean, maybe he'd even agree with that. And that now you're taking the opposite extreme.  You're saying the only way to administer this, is the only thing really you can do with it, is you can sell it to a Federal -- through a Federal firearms dealer.  And there are probably intermediate positions. Alderson Reporting Company You know, I mean, somebody has a very valuable antique weapon the Normans used to shoot or something.  And he says, I don't want to sell it.  I'm going to be able to possess it again in ten years.  They'll forgive me for whatever it is, and maybe you should accommodate that, or maybe you shouldn't. I have no feeling for how important it is to have an absolute rule.  You've given some good reasons for it.  What am I supposed to do?  Just say everybody agrees here you can't sell it your best friend who will keep it to you, so they're wrong on that rule.  The government's position's is now let's do something else with it.  Maybe absolute.  Maybe not.  Go work it out, Eleventh Circuit.  Go work it out, lower court.  What should we do?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is this Federal license --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Sold -- that is -- is it the government's position that it's the licensed firearm dealer or -- in effect, forfeited to the government?  Is there any other transferee in the government's view that would be appropriate?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But it would have to be sold, but the sale would be -- or the consignment would be to a licensed dealer.  You're rejecting the friends. You're rejecting the wife.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Can he select the FFL?  Can he select the Federal -- I mean, you know, suppose the government says we want it sold by a firearms dealer in San Francisco and he says, what?  You know, they don't sell any guns in San Francisco.  I want it -- you know, I want it in -- in Dallas. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Can -- can he pick the firearms dealer?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Justice -- Justice Alito.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, what would happen if someone is on trial for a felony and has in -- in his house a number of firearms and then the person is convicted?  So what -- how can that person deal with the firearms in the house without exercising constructive possession in your view?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, then why can't we do that here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean, your whole argument -- the reason I took it that the government wants this firearm thing, firearm dealer, is they say, look, there are a lot of guns and these guns should be safe and we're afraid he'll give them to a friend, and we're afraid maybe the gang boss will get them, and the only safe thing to do is really the firearms dealer. Okay.        But now we think of a similar kind of case.  It's just happened that the government didn't get the guns first, they're in his house.  And then you say well, the solution there is it's a reasonable time.  He Alderson Reporting Company has a reasonable time to do with them what he wants.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: As long as he gets them out of his possession.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Are you going to say he has to give them to a firearms dealer?  This is very complicated, more so than I ever thought, and it seems to me that it might best be worked out by lower courts under the principle that we don't want these guns back in the hands of either his control or people who might misuse them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Can you tell me -- it's Alderson Reporting Company not this case, but suppose -- somewhat like Justice Alito's hypothetical -- a man's living at home with his wife.  Wife owns the firearms.  The firearms are in the bedroom.  He's convicted of an offense where 922(g) controls.  Is he in constructive possession of those in violation of the statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But the mere fact that his wife has them is not enough --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- for constructive possession.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you say that in this context, the mere fact that a friend of his would have them is enough for constructive possession.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why is that? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Ms. O'Connell, I think it's implicit in what you're saying, but I just wanted to make it clear.  Although you say that Rule 41(g) is not the appropriate mechanism, you have no doubt that courts do have the equitable authority to do this.  Is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Would you agree that the Unclean Hands part, that should not remain the law of Alderson Reporting Company the circuit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So we should -- we should address that and reject it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But you have to file for forfeiture in those situations.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What about just forgetting the words "dominion" and "constructive" and just look to the word "possession" and say that that sometimes includes control?  And what you want to prevent is that he disposes of these arms in a way that allows him, possibly, to control them in the future or control them now in a way that likely puts them in the hands of bad Alderson Reporting Company people for the future. Now, that way, all we have to do is look at the word possession.  We have to add that it includes, for purposes of this statute, certain kinds of control. And then you have to say this is the simple rule, and this will prevent two bad kinds of control. Now, is there something wrong with that?        If so, we then send it back so that you can argue to the district court why your rule is necessary to prevent these two bad kinds of control.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I know, that's the part that it's hard for me to accept.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because you're willing to allow that control in the case that Justice Alito put where he was convicted and it's in his house.  And I Alderson Reporting Company don't see anything bad that flows from that kind of control.  And I don't see why you have to read the statute to include that kind of control to achieve any purpose that the statute has.  So therefore, I tend, tentatively, to reject that kind of control as falling within what the statute forbids.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What bad will happen?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That might be another way to do it, you know.  All right.  You have a difficult conceptual case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Would the firearms dealer Alderson Reporting Company charge a commission for selling these guns?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And who would pay that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So that if the -- if the convicted felon could sell this without going through a dealer for a certain amount, then that person would lose the commission by having it sold through a firearms dealer?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You can finish your sentence.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Alderson Reporting Company Mr. Ortiz, you have 14 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You -- you started off -- you were going to give us five pages in -- in the record, and you only got to two of them, I think.  You want --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Just in case I'm unfortunate enough to get assigned this opinion. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Ortiz, you do understand -- I thought it was clear from what the government said earlier, that it's waived any claim -- that you waived the request for this relief.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So that's not at issue. You think there's still --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- they're going to go back down and say that you're not entitled to the relief because you didn't ask for the right relief?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
